Award.AwardTitle: Research Initiation Award - Spatial and Temporal Modeling of Mercury Fate and Dynamics in Tennessee Watersheds

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
Research Initiation Awards provide support for junior and mid-career faculty at Historically Black Colleges and Universities who are building new research programs or redirecting and rebuilding existing research programs. It is expected that the award helps to further the faculty member's research capability and effectiveness, improves research and teaching at his home institution, and involves undergraduate students in research experiences. The project at Texas Southern University has potential broader impact in a number of areas. The goal of the project is to develop a comprehensive understanding of the landscape factors on mercury loading and distribution in the East Tennessee watersheds of the Oak Ridge Reservation. This project will also enhance the research experience and training of undergraduate and graduate students at Texas Southern University.

The three specific objectives of the project include: characterizing the spatial and temporal trends of mercury bioaccumulation in watersheds; identifying and analyzing the influence of land use and land cover changes on the mercury dynamics in the watersheds; and investigating the fate and transport of mercury across the landscape. The first objective will be achieved by acquiring, assembling and interpreting both the spatial and long-term analytical data of all the sample media of the watersheds that drain the Oak Ridge reservation. Spatial and temporal analysis of the data will be conducted to identify the mercury concentration and bioaccumulation trends. The second objective will be achieved by quantifying the land use and land cover changes using time series aerial and satellite imagery. Quantitative relationships between the changes in landscape factors to mercury bioaccumulation will be established. The third objective will be achieved by superimposing and analyzing the hydrologic flow paths with watershed delineations, soil and sediment erosion rates, wetlands and other landscape factors with the available long term mercury analytical data.

POR.DRECONTENT:
PROJECT OUTCOMES REPORT

Over the past several decades, substantial environmental and ecological changes have occurred in streams that have historically received pollutant discharges. One of the largest contaminant released is mercury (Hg), a significant environmental pollutant due to its persistence in the environment, ability to bioaccumulate in food chains, and its known hazards to both human and wildlife. The bioaccumulation of Hg in fish has proven to be enigmatic in the creeks of Oak Ridge Reservation (ORR) watersheds over the past several years, with remedial actions at industrial facilities successfully decreasing total Hg concentrations in water, but not resulting in commensurate decreases in fish Hg concentrations. The primary goal of this project is to develop a comprehensive understanding of the landscape factors on Hg loading and distribution in the East Tennessee watersheds of ORR. Specific objectives of the project include; 1) Characterizing the spatial and temporal trends of Hg bioaccumulation in watersheds, 2) Identify and analyze the influence of land use and land cover changes on the Hg dynamics in the watersheds, and 3) Investigate the fate and transport of Hg across the landscape.

This project involves development of geospatial database that includes acquiring and assembling both the geographical and tabular data for the study area of EFPC watershed. Geographical data layers that includes county and watershed boundaries, rivers, streams, soils, geology, and land cover datasets were collected from various sources. The primary datasets that are being used for interpreting land use and land cover and other landscape features are: National Hydrology Datasets (NHDs), USGS National Map Viewer data, flood hazard data (FEMA), SSURGO soils data (NRCS USDA), aerial imagery and high resolution DEM data (OREIS), Tennessee Federal GIS data server (TNGIS), National Wetlands Inventory (NWI), ORNL Shared Data Initiative (SDI) data and Landsat imagery (USGS). The Hg concentrations of biota, soil, sediment and water along with other physical and chemical parameters for the time interval of 1985-2013 were downloaded from the Oak Ridge Environmental Information System (OREIS; http://www-oreis.bechteljacobs.org/ oreis/help /oreishome. html).

Intellectual Merit: The intellectual merit of this project is the development of comprehensive understanding of the landscape factors on Hg loading and distribution in watersheds. A comprehensive geospatial database was developed that incorporated all the spatial and analytical data from all the separate research studies that were carried out for the past several years at EFPC. The spatial and temporal analysis indicated the trends in Hg accumulation in different media (such as soil, sediment and biota samples) and the locations where the Hg concentrations are relatively high within the EFPC watershed. The Hg analytical data and the GIS cluster analysis indicated that the bioaccumulation of Hg in Redbreast sunfish showed an increasing trend in Lower EFPC (LEFPC) compared to Upper EFPC (UEFPC). The spatial interpolation analysis of Hg concentrations in soils and sediments showed higher Hg levels at certain locations along the LEFPC. The Hg concentrations in the soil and sediment were also visualized in Arc Scene using the 3D analyst tools. The soil and sediment Hg concentrations were high in the surroundings of EFK 18.2 location (EFK stands for East Fork Kilometer). The cluster and spatial interpolation analysis helped to identify the ‘hot spots’ of Hg concentrations in soil and sediments across the EFPC. Also the satellite image analysis showed that the impervious surface area decreases and the vegetative cover increases downstream along the creek from UEFPC to LEFPC.

Broader Impacts: The project impacted the broader society through education, training and hands-on research experience for undergraduate and graduate students from Texas Southern University, so that more under-represented minorities can successfully enter the fields of environmental and interdisciplinary sciences. A total of four undergraduate and one graduate minority students, successfully completed an intensive ten-week summer internship program at Oak Ridge National Lab (ORNL), where the students are exposed to different research techniques in remote sensing, GIS, environmental sampling and analysis. Two graduate students have successfully developed research projects, defended and graduated with a MS degree in Environmental Toxicology from TSU. This project helped the students to gain training and experience in solving environmental problems and in preparing them for professional careers in industry, government and non-profit organizations. The project also uniquely impacted the undergraduate students to consider the research in environmental sciences and to pursue the M.S. and Ph.D. programs in their areas of interest and will enable to increase the enrollment of graduate students who opt for majoring in the STEM field of studies here at TSU.
